awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Chemical Tools for Understanding the Mycomembrane of the Corynebacterineae
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Benjamin Swarts at Central Michigan University to investigate the structure and dynamics of a unique cell membrane present in hundreds of bacterial species of the suborder Corynebacterineae. All bacteria have cell envelopes with one or two membranes that play critical roles in cellular defense, communication, and structural integrity. Species in the Corynebacterineae have two membranes, the outermost of which is composed mostly of complex sugar-linked lipids called mycolic acid conjugates. This "mycomembrane" is unique to the Corynebacterineae and gives them distinctive physiological and pathogenic characteristics. Many aspects of the production, maintenance, and composition of the mycomembrane remain unknown because of the challenges encountered when using standard experimental techniques. This project generates and utilizes new chemical biology tools to characterize the structure and dynamics of the mycomembrane. The tools being developed form a significant part of the process of acquiring a better understanding of how the Corynebacterineae survive within and adapt to their surrounding environment. In addition, an investigation of this bacterial system advances understanding of the nature of interactions of bacteria with the environment and provides information that would enhance efforts to gain environmental control of pathogens. Undergraduate students and postdoctoral fellows working on this research acquire interdisciplinary training in organic synthesis, microbiology and proteomics. This research is also integrated into an outreach program that introduces community college students to chemical bacteriology research and encourages their continued education in science. The tools generated in this project are expected to have broad utility and to support other scientists pursuing basic and applied research on the Corynebacterineae.

Traditional biochemical and molecular biological approaches are not well-suited to investigating the mycomembrane because it is made up largely of non-genetically encoded lipids and sugars. This research project develops chemical probes that exploit native metabolic pathways to introduce tags into specific mycomembrane components in intact bacterial cells. Tagged molecules are then imaged or identified by mass spectrometry, depending on the goal of the experiment. The probes developed in this project provide information on (i) how the major glycolipid constituents of the mycomembrane are synthesized and remodeled when the bacterium encounters stress; and (ii) what proteins reside within and contribute to the construction and maintenance of the mycomembrane. The findings from this project will lead to an improved understanding of mycomembrane structure and dynamics and provide insight into the physiology of bacteria in the Corynebacterineae suborder.

por.por_cntn:
The mycomembrane is a remarkably complex outer membrane that envelopes hundreds of bacterial species in the Corynebacterineae suborder, many of which are important for biotechnology, the environment, and/or human and animal health. Despite its importance, the lack of research tools for analyzing the mycomembrane’s molecular components—including many unique and complex lipid, sugar, and protein molecules—has obscured key aspects of what the mycomembrane is composed of, how it is constructed and maintained, and how it functions in the bacterium’s environment. Advancing knowledge on these topics is critical not only for gaining a fundamental understanding of the physiology of the Corynebacterineae, but also capitalizing on this knowledge to enable applied research, such as improving fermentation technologies to produce valuable chemicals and developing antibiotics and diagnostics to address challenging bacterial infections. The goal of this project was to develop and harness new chemistry-driven tools to advance knowledge of the mycomembrane composition, construction, and maintenance. These tools, referred to as chemical probes, enable the analysis of specific mycomembrane molecular components and processes in their native setting, intact bacterial cells.

The intellectual merit of this project was underpinned by the tool development and applications occurring in the project’s three Aims. The first Aim of this project led to the development of a toolbox of chemical probes that allowed monitoring of the synthesis and degradation of the mycomembrane’s major lipid components. The new capabilities provided by this toolbox were enlisted to reveal molecular details of how the Corynebacterineae dynamically alter their mycomembrane in response to cellular stress, e.g., the bacteria break down trehalose-linked mycolates to recycle sugar and fortify arabinogalactan-linked mycolates in an energy-efficient manner. Some of the tools developed under Aim 1 have possible applications related to the detection of bacterial pathogens. The second and third Aims of the project led to the development of new chemical probes and strategies to identify and characterize mycomembrane proteins, i.e., proteins that reside within and/or contribute to the construction and maintenance of the mycomembrane. Application of the probes and strategies developed in Aims 2 and 3 led to new information about proteins are either directly modified by or indirectly interact with abundant lipids within the mycomembrane, thus providing insight into the membrane’s protein composition. Collaborative studies that deployed these probes helped to reveal mechanisms by which the mycomembrane is thought to be assembled. In the long term, such tools and information could provide insights for the development of new treatments for bacterial infections.

The broader impacts of this project relate to its broadening and uniting of the fields of chemical biology and microbiology, specifically the study of mycobacteria. Collectively, the chemical probes developed through this project represent an enabling technology that are expected to be used by the mycobacteria research community in the future to further advance knowledge of the mycomembrane. In addition, the broader impact of the project was connected to its in-depth involvement of student trainees, including through a community college outreach program. This outreach program utilized research experience, mentoring, and academic advising to encourage community college students from the mid-Michigan region to continue their STEM education and successfully transition to and graduate from a 4-year institution. The program was highly effective in promoting these goals, as nearly all participating students completed degrees in STEM and transitioned to graduate school or employment in their fields. At the same time, the outreach program enhanced and increased awareness and appreciation of the interdisciplinary field of chemical bacteriology. Thus, the program concurrently promoted STEM education at the community college level and promoted the field of chemical bacteriology.
